video.title: Learn Webpack - Full Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn Webpack from Colt Steele in this full tutorial course.  It begins with a simple question: "What is webpack?"  Quickly we move on to installing Webpack, configuring it, and adding loaders for CSS, SASS, HTML, and Files.  The course covers cache busting, setting up a dev server, and splitting up your development and production config files. We incorporate multiple Webpack plugins including clean-webpack-plugin, mini-css-extract-plugin,  optimize-css-assets-webpack-plugin, terser-webpack-plugin, and html-webpack-plugin.  It's a lot of stuff :) 

💻 Code and commits: https://github.com/Colt/webpack-demo-app

🔗 Colt Steele's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrqAGUPPMOdo0jfQ6grikZw
🔗 Colt Steele's Udemy courses: https://www.udemy.com/user/coltsteele/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) What Even Is Webpack??
⌨️ (0:08:12) Installing and Running Webpack and Webpack-CLI
⌨️ (0:22:18) Imports, Exports, & Webpack Modules
⌨️ (0:29:58) Configuring Webpack
⌨️ (0:38:57) Loaders, CSS, & SASS
⌨️ (0:53:55) Cache Busting and Plugins
⌨️ (1:07:13) Splitting Dev & Production
⌨️ (1:17:13) Html-loader, File-loader, & Clean-webpack
⌨️ (1:28:17) Multiple Entrypoints & Vendor.js
⌨️ (1:34:45) Extract CSS & Minify HTML/CSS/JS

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: Liam Sarsfield
replies.text:
​@Mac Cast In that scenario, IMO yeah you wouldn't separate those if statements into separate files. Though you might have a function inside the first if statement that does the clicking of the object and another function in the if statement for hovering on the object, etc. Then you might want to call those functions in different places so to not repeat the code again (DRY principle).
From what you're describing it sounds like this 3d scene would be one "component"/file (as modern JS frameworks) call it with multiple functions inside it. These functions would execute your hovering and clicking actions but would only have the scope (be able to be triggered) in that component/file.
If I were you I would stick all the code for that 3d scene into the same file with different functions. But for example,  if you wanted to create a separate page that would allow you to draw something, I would then put that code into a separate file.
I would recommend looking at Vue or React JS frameworks if you want to understand why webpack would be useful, though I would strongly recommend following a web development roadmap that guides you through the basics first

replies.author: Mac Cast
replies.text: @Liam Sarsfield i already finished making my website though. I spent a whole month making a nice 3d scene using three.js. that's it. The shapes move when you click on them. It's just a simple page and i wanted to upload it so my grandparents can see it in Mexico. That's it. So i don't think it would be efficient to separate the if statement for clicking on the object from the if statement for hovering on the object. Would I? It seems so counterintuitive

replies.author: Liam Sarsfield
replies.text:
You shouldn't be following this tutorial if you don't understand why modularizing (breaking up) your JS into separate files is needed.
I would recommend following a web development roadmap if you want to make a website from scratch, otherwise Wix or other services would be better if you just want to make a website fast

For webpack-dev-server, use "webpack server --config webpack.dev.js" instead (the commmand has  changed)
Also, if you want to use --open, do it in the webpack.dev.js by adding
devServer: {
    open: true,
  },

If you want to use it in the CLI command, you'll have to specify the browser name but the prob is that browser name accepted is different in each OS.
But if you specify it in the config file (webpack.dev.js) with true, it'll open in the default browser

topLevelComment.author: Lazarlux
topLevelComment.text:
the entire web dev stack based on node is complete mess and a timebomb.  To add some minor things like merging two config files, we need to install a node module (with a new raft of dependencies). To extract css into a file we need to install something called plugin (with name Mini??) which has a method to return a loader; by the way loaders and plugins are disparate tools, aimed at different problems. Then to minify it we need another module. 
Why not to up the ante, if we need to use console, then include a module, if we need to use oprator +, then include a module.

topLevelComment.author: Noopur Phalak
topLevelComment.text:
In the latest version of HtmlWebpackPlugin, you don't have to specify the minify option, the index.html is minified by default.
Also, if you are using webpack v5, then CSS is minified by default, no need to install optimize-css-assets-webpack-plugin.
Also, Webpack v5 does not come with terser-webpack-plugin pre-installed, you need to install it using npm.

topLevelComment.author: Noopur Phalak
topLevelComment.text:
Also, you should now import the clean-webpack-plugin as follows:

const {CleanWebpackPlugin} = require("clean-webpack-plugin")

topLevelComment.author: Noopur Phalak
topLevelComment.text: For those who are facing issues like "Automatic publicPath is not supported in this browser", you need to declare publicPath: './' in your output configuration.

topLevelComment.author: Noopur Phalak
topLevelComment.text:
If you are using webpack-cli > 4.0.0 and webpack-dev-server >= 3.11.0, use the following command in the package.json to use webpack-dev-server:

"start": "webpack serve --config webpack.dev.js"

topLevelComment.author: theYOFFLISES
topLevelComment.text:
I fully agree this amazing video brings a big deal to deeply understand what to do with WebPack for a highly tuned bundle.
Now when I bootstrap a new project for example with Vue CLI, it gives a profound understanding of how this all is scaffolded.

However for those who now consider themselves as kind of Webpack ninjas (as seen in the comments), I would say, speaking about me first, we are still miles away to understand how plugins, loaders, etc work and articulate themselves. Another big step required to master this as well.
Another step would also be to understand the why and how of source maps.

Some comments:
1/ I noticed css-loader is not strictly necessary for me, before style-loader which injects into the DOM (on a project using no sass but post-css to have modern CSS compatible with IE). However, strangely, MiniCssExtractPlugin.loader requires it.
2/ Speaking about vendor.js, I was surprised we need to explicitly install dependencies (such as jquery and popper) to make bootstrap work. It looks it kind of defeats dependency management which primary purpose is to handle this. My hope is this need is limited to first tear of dependencies not the whole tree when many dependencies are involved.
3/ In the production configuration, HtmlWebpackPlugin was inserted in the optimization section. It works. However seems more logical for me to place it in the plugins section. It works too.

Finally, thank you for this fantastic video. It has it all. Highly recommended.

replies.author: theYOFFLISES
replies.text:
Following the examples in the video, here is what I did to enable source maps:
In dev mode, just add <<devtool: "inline-source-map">> in relevant Webpack configuration file,
In prod mode, configure TerserPlugin like this <<new TerserPlugin({ sourceMap: true })>> and add <<devtool: "source-map">> in relevant Webpack configuration file.

topLevelComment.author: Jason Barr
topLevelComment.text:
Excellent tutorial, Colt. As always, you have a knack for breaking things down in a way that actually makes sense. I've muddled through a sea of confusing Webpack tutorials and this is one of the few that's clear yet still doesn't shy away from demonstrating how powerful Webpack can be.


Important note for anyone watching this as of 21 November 2019: clean-webpack-plugin recently released v3.0 which contains a breaking change from what's seen here. You now have to destructure the assignment, so:


const { CleanWebpackPlugin } = require("clean-webpack-plugin")


Hope that helps anyone else who may have gotten tripped up by that.
